div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: The Channel Tunnel.
div.p: The narrow streak of water which separates England from France has made out country what it is. Now we are concerned in abolishing it-that is, not the water, but the inconveniences to which it subjects us. Those inconveniences do not consist entirely in the racking of the constitution to which the crossing of the Channel exposes poor sailors, though for that last reason alone many of us have wished at one time or another that the Channel could be either bridged or obliterated. In calm moments neither the recollection of personal suffrings nor the realization of the bigger drawbacks to commerce and travel can persuade us to ingratitude towards the Channel. We rejoice that it shows no disposition to dry up, and we are more than content that the schemes for tunneling beneath it have met with small acceptation.

There is another way, however, of rendering the Chance less inconvenient. Oil-train oil can be thrown on the troubled waters. A
P&O Weekly Mail and Passenger Services

ferry could be made; probably will be made. The scheme was explained in some detail at a meeting of the British Chamber of Commerce in Paris. The president, Mr. Boddington, read a paper showing what might be done at a comparatively small cost. Moreover, we should not have very long to wait for the facilities. Whereas a tunnel, even if it were approved on grounds of public policy, would occupy many years in construction and cost millions variously estimated at from eight to twenty, a ferry could be set working in two years, and would entail an expenditure of less than one million. There is one strong argument in favour of the ferry. We could use it ourselves. We should not be obliged to construct it, with melancholy side-glances on the shortness of human lite, for the benefit of those who are to come after us.

It is true that among the other benefits of the ferry the abolition of sea-sickness would not be included. Perhaps our pangs would be less agonising than at present. After experience of the inadequacy of "infallible" remedies the cautious prophet is unwilling to commit himself on the point So much is tolerably certain, however, that the torment of prospection and retrospection would be lessened. The journey would not be broken; it would be completed in quicker time; therefore, we should not have so long to brood over the woe to come and the woe that is past. Having been run down to Dover, our train would be ran on to the ferry-boat, the travellers remaining comfortably in their compartments, and would be conveyed over the water by a swift turbine. Arrived at Calais, it would be restored to the metals, passengers still remaining in their seats, and be taken to Paris without let or hindrance. The gain in time would be much. The gain in comfort would be more. At its worst, the scheme promises to contrast with the present method as favourably as an express railway journey compares with a journey made in stopping trains and accompanied by the wretched necessity of changes.

Seem to have regarded it only as a provisional expedientsomething that will serve very well indeed until a project for tunnelling the Channel is carried into effect. We have already expressed our conviction of the insuperable disadvantages of this bigger scheme. 0n grounds of public policy we believe it will be better for all parties that the Channel shall not be undermined.

It has served as well in the past, and will continue to serve us well; but if sacrilegious bands be laid upon it, the way may be paved for trouble that our great-great grandchildren will be compelled to grapple with amid curses on the temerity of their forefathers. No such objection can be urged to a Channel ferry. It would leave us as beneficially islanded and isolated as we are now. At the same time, it would bring us into closer communication with the Continent.

div.head: Roumania and Egypt.
div.p: The Roumanian Government intends to open a commercial museum at Alexandria.

div.head: The Hedjaz Railway.
div.p: The railway to Mecca has been completed as far as kilometre 764, that is, up to El Ahdar.

div.head: Cambling Hell Raided.
div.p: The police made a raid yesterday on a gambling hell at Minet-el-Bassal kept by a native.

div.head: Cattle Markets.
div.p: The cattle markets in Menoufish province have been reopened by the authorisation of the Ministry of the Interior.

div.head: Hashieh Seizure.
div.p: The Coast Guard or fiscasted 12 parcels of hashish which two local Turks were attempting to smuggle from the S.S. Osmanieh.

div.head: Coods Train on Fire.
div.p: A fire broke out on a goods train between Minieh and Cairo. Five trucks full of cotton were destroyed. The damage is estimated at *3,000.

div.head: All Saints' Church, Ramieh.
div.p: We are requested to state that the Rev. A.H. Ellaby, M.A., has assumed charge of this church for the winter months, and has taken up his residence, with his daughter, at the Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley.

div.head: Military Lectures.
div.p: The first of the series of military lecutures in the winter season, inaugurated last year, will be delivered this evening by the General Officer Commanding in the model room at Head quarters. Cairo, the subject being "Training for War."

div.head: Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helouan.
div.p: This magnificent establishment is now open oof on band nights border. The L.E. 48. The expenses for the year amounted to L.E. 4,246.

div.head: The "Season."
div.p: Mena House Hotel, although only opened on November 1, is rapidly filling up. The number of visitors already staying at this favourite resort is very considerably in advance of any previous year. Amongst the latest arrivals we notice: Mr. and Mrs. Andrews and family, Mr. and Mrs. Littlewood, Mr. and Mrs. A. Perry, Colonel and Mrs. Ludlow, Dr. and Mrs. Wakeling, Rev. and Mrs. Urquhart, Dr. and Mrs. Fischer, Mrs. A. Wood, Miss H. Morrison, Mr. Y.H. Swinson, Mr. Charles F. Higgins, Mr. Watson, Miss Bentham, Miss Hallett, Mr. W.G. Hayter and family, Miss Spencer Wigram, Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Allen, Mr. Y. O'Sullivan, Mr. B.F. de Bailly, Mr. A. de Cramer.

div.head: Merchant Seamen's Home.
div.p: The usual Friday evening concerts for the winter were resumed at the Merchant Seamen's Home last Friday, when an interesting and varied programme was gone through. It included two sketches, entitled "As Deaf as a Post" and "April Fools," the leading parts in which were taken by Mr. J. Walsh, Mr. S. Price, and Mr. Wallace. Songs were also contributed during the evening by Mrs. Reid, Messrs. Collins, Wallace, and Price. Mr. Addie gave a flute solo which was very well received, and Mr. Gilmour, who also acted as accompanist, gave an enjoyable violin solo. Mr. Manning's banjo election was much appreciated. Tea was served in the interval, and the proceedings concluded with "God save the King."

div.head: The Carrison Directory.
div.p: The Garrison Directory for the season 1906-7 will be published (under authority of the General Officer Commanding the Force in Egypt) this week. Further editions will appear in January and March. The price will be P.T. 5 as heretofore. This handy little volume is much appreciated by British and Egyptian Government Officials, and residents generally, containing, as it does, a complete directory to the Army of Occupation, The Egyptian Army, and all the Egyptian Government Departments, as well as many useful tables and other matter. It also includes a list of residents, with their addresses. This list is kept as up-to-date as possible but residents would greatly enhance its value by notifying the editor of any change of address, or any inaccuracy they may have observed. A limited number of advertisements is also insterted in the directory; terms may be ascertained on application to the Manager, Advertisement Dept., British Head Quarters, Cairo.

div.head: Rodah Bridge.
div.p: Unsatisfactory Work.

The report of the Public Works Ministry upon the administration of that department for 1905 bes just made its appearance. Besides Sir William Garstin's report, it includes reports by Mr. A.L. Webb, C.M.G., Under Secretary of State for Irrigation in Egypt; Mr. C.E. Dupuis, Inspector General of Irrigation in the Sudan; Mr. A.H. Perry, Under Secretary of State for Towns and Buildings; Mohammed Anis Pasha, Director of the Technical Service; Monsieur G. Maspero, Director General of the Antiquities Department; Mr. Gunn, Government Inspector for Agricultural Railways; Johnson Paslia, Comptroller of the Model Workshop; Captain Stanley Flower, Director of the Government Zoological Gardens, Ghizeh.

An interesting feature of the report is Mr. Perry's remarks on the Nile bridge which is now being constructed to connect Rodah Island and Ghizeh. The bridge was contracted for by Sir William Arrol and Company, but it appears that the work is being done in a far from satisfactory manner.
Commenting upon the erecting and rivetting, Mr. Perry writes:-

"This work has up to now been anything but a credit to a firm of Messrs. Arrol's standing. The supervision has, for the most part, been worthless and the work has been put together in the style of the village blacksmith. On the Ghizeh side, under our inspector, Mr. Kent's, direction, matters have improved a great deal, the foreman being ready to learn. On the Rodsh side, the foreman, who was perfectly useless, has at last been dismissed and a new one has arrived. The new general foreman-who arrived in the middle of September-is really looking after things and there is now a semblance of discipline on the work.
The rivetting has been very bad. On the Rodsh side about 8% of the rivets put in by to provide a remedy.

Native workmen are employed hed on the ting who have no experience of the and pneumatic tools they have to hopeless to expect good work without supervision only men with experience in particular tools used, and Messrs, Arrol only now in December, promised to send men from England for this purpose.

"The hydraulic rivetting machines in use here are unsuited for the execution of much of the work in the main girders, and this will have to be done by the pneumatic hammer or by hand. Hydraulic machines adopted for the rivets which are difficult of access are employed on other works. Messrs, Arrol, however, do not seem inclined to introduce them."

div.head: Old Marlburians In Egypt and Sudan.
div.p: Mr. Ralph Neville, Beni Souef, writes :-I venture to ask for the hospitality of your columns to reach old Marlburians resident in Egypt or the Sudan. A desire has emanated from Marlborough for a complete list of Marlburians employed in the Government Service, or the Army of Occupation, or otherwise, in these countries; and I have undertaken to compile such a list. May I therefore ask all old Marlburians to be good enough to send me in their names and occupations (with the year of their entry at Marlbourough)? In the event of anyone being absent on leave perhaps some friend would kindly send in the names.

div.head: National University Scheme.
div.p: "Al Minbar" publishes a letter which contains the following remarks:-"It is really annoying to see the subscriptions for the National University coming in so slowly, especially after the appointment of the new Minister. Here is a suggestion from one of our financiers: Suppose the Government were to authorise a lottery of 500,000 numbers at L.E. 1 a piece, L.E. 100,000 to go to pay the winning numbers, and L.E. 400,000 to the University chest. The National Bank to organise the sale of tickets, the drawing of the lots to be public, and the payment in cash.
"Al Minbar" approves of the idea, yet somehow we cannot quite see the Government and the National Bank puffing the scheme.

div.head: Silence is Golden.
div.p: "Al Lewa" publishes another open letter addressed to Lord Cromer by a number of natives who call upon the British Government to fulfill its old promise of granting a constitution to Egypt. The following is an extract from the letter :-

"Several full days have elapsed since we submitted our first petition to your Lordship, while we, and every other native, are waiting for a fulfilment of England's promises, but unfortunately our only answer so far has been a deep silence both from England and your Lordship.

div.head: Egypt in Parliament.
div.p: An Egyptian Group.

A private meeting of Liberal members was held at the House of Commons on the evening of the 25th ulto., when those present resolved themselves into a committee to watch any points arising in Parliament with reference to Egypt, especially as affecting native interests.

A querulous correspondent, who writes to complain of the delay in publishing the report of the Ministry of Public Works, suggests that a question should be asked on the subject in the House of Commons, as such a proceeding might assist in expediting matters and prevent officials year after year from treating a matter of such interest without any regard to the interests of the public. We do not consider that this course of tactics will have any effect, for it is the wise policy of the Government to reply to any question about Egypt with an evasive answer. If, for example, a question were put on the subject of the delay in issuing this report, the answer would probably be:-

"There is no information in the Foreign Office and the matter is one which concerns the Egyptian Government, and in which neither his Majesty's Government nor their representatives exercise influence."
The Futility of Questions.

The futility of asking questions is obvious, for this sort of answer is frequently employed, as the reports in the "Parliamentary Debates" show. To cite only one instance, which will suffice for all such cases. Last July Mr. J. W. Robertson asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he could give particulars of these cases in which, since the British Occupation, pensions had been awarded out of the Egyptian revenues to former English officials of the Egyptian Ministry of Finance, indicating the amounts and the number of years' service of the respective pensioners. The object which inspired this question is difficult to discover, as the names of the recipients of such pensions are given regulary in the Budget, and the chief names in this connection are those of the late Sir Elwin Palmer and Sir Eldon Gorst, to whom special pensions were given. To anybody with the slightest acquaintance with Egypt it is clear that neither of these pensions could have been granted without the cognisance and approval of Lord Cromer; yet Sir Edward Grey in his reply declared that the British Representative did not exercise any influence in the matter, which concerned the Egyptian Government.
To ask questions on matters concerning in the House of Commons is a work of
Question in Parliament.

Colonel Lockwood asked the Financial Secretary to the War Office in the House of Commons this day week what allowance the Government would make to the married officers and non-commissioned officers of the Coldstream Guards to meet the expenses of their journey to Egypt and their return twelve month hence.

Mr. Buchanan (Financial Secretary to the War Office)-These officers and non-commissioned officers will receive the usual regulated allowances. It is not intended to treat this battalion in respect of the expenses of its move differently from other Infantry battalions.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: The 319 vessels which went through the Canal during October were of the following description: 221 cargo boats, 81 mailboats, 12 warships and 5 in ballast. The aggregate net tonnage on which tell was levied was 1,107,029.55 tons, made up as follows :- Great Britain 744,709.89 tons; Germany 221,169.63 tons; France 71,038.92 tons; Holland 50,556.81 tons; America 21.140.67 tons; Russia 21,028.51 tons; Austria 20,135.11 tons; Japan 16,734.12 tons; Italy 12,082.15 tons; Denmark 10,965.49 tons; Norway 5,817.18 tons; Spain 5,630.16 tons; Sweden 2,730.81 tons; Turkey 2,290 tons.

On November 3 and 4, 10 vessels, 7 northward and 3 southward bound, transited the Canal, and paid transit and passenger toll Fr. 263,605.76 Of these vessels, 7 were British, 1 German, 1 Italian, and 1 Austrian. The total revenue since November 1 is Fr. 1,066,503.81.
During this period, 43 vessels transited the Canal, 27 northward and 16 southward bound.

div.head: STEAMER Movements.
div.p: The Ellerman liner City of Cambridge arrived at Manchester yesterday.
The Moss liner Tabor arrived this morning from Liverpool, via Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Moss liner Meneptha arrived at Liverpool on Sunday morning.

div.head: Census of the Sinai.
div.p: Kaimakam Parker Bey has been appointed Commandant of the Sinai Peninsula.

We understand that the services of Jennings Bramly Bey are required by the Government for the Bedouia census. Mr. Bramly's knowledge of the Bedouin of Egypt and the Sinai makes him eminently qualified for what must be a colossal task.
We believe that a serious attempt is being made to arrive at as accurate an estimate as possible of the numbers of all the nomad tribes in the whole of the Egyptian territory.

div.head: King's Birthday Celebrations.
div.p: Cairo.
The troops in the Cairo garrison, detailed below, will parade in the Abdeen Square on Friday, 9th inst. at 9:20 a.m. The troops will be parsaded as follows:
On the west side of the square, facing East:
"U" Battery, R.H.A.
6th Inniskilling Dragoons.
On the north side of the square, facing South, in line of quarter columns, at 6 paces interval:
Mounted Infantry.
2nd Co., R.E.
3rd Bn. Coldstream Guards.
1st Bn. Lancashire Fusiliers.
2nd Bn. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers.
2nd Bn. Royal Berks. Regt.
The troops will enter the square as follows:-
Mounted troops by Esbekieh, National Bank, and Sharia-el-Boustan.
Other units from Abbassieh, and troops from Citadel, by Abdeen Street.
Kasr-el-Nil troops by Sharia-el-Boustan.
A Royal salute will be fired during the parade from the Citadel.
Lord Cromer, who will attend the review, will be escorted from the British Agency to Abdeen-square by military mounted police.
ALEXANDRIA.

At Alexandria a salute of 21 guns will be fired from Fort Kom-el-Dik at 12 noon. At the same hour the troops of the Army of Occupation, paraded on the polo ground of the Alexandria Sporting Club, will fire a feu de joie. They will afterwards march past, advance in review order, and give a Royal salute.

div.head: The Khedive.
div.p: A huissier has been delegated specially to notify the "actes" of the Bank to the fellaheen.

The London Stock Exchange Committee have ordered the under-mentioned security to be quoted in the Official List: Agricultural Bank of Egypt, *1,570,000 Sterling 3 ½ per Cent. Guaranteed Bonds, Nos. 1 to 12,000 of *100 and 100,001 to 118,500 of *20 each.

div.head: Upper Nile Dredging.
div.p: By a special Ministerial Order, Mr. Dupuis was deputed to visit America at the end of his leave last year, and collect information as to recent methods and practice in dredging in Canada and the United States, with a view to seeing if any of those methods promised well for application to the problem presented by the proposed improvement of the Upper Nile.
Much most interesting information was collected in a tour of about six weeks' duration, upon which a report will be shortly submitted.

div.head: Constantinople Notes.
div.p: Egypt and Bulgaria.
(From Our Correspondent.)
Pera, October 29.

The relations between Egypt and Bulgaria are becoming closer and closer, and almost each day sees an increase in the interchange of trade between the two countries. According to an official report just issued at Sophia, Bulgarian imports into Egypt during last year exceeded that country's imports from Egypt by frs. 416,953, the latter showing a falling off of frs. 27, 315 as compared with 1904. Egypt's exports from Bulgaria increased by frs. 115,639, and the entire trade between the two countries has increased since 1904 by frs. 88,294.
A Schismatic Partiarchate.

The visit of Mgr. Photius, Orthodox Patriarch of Alexandria, to Constantinope, has for first object an act of homage to the Sultan, but it is really to solve the question of the Patriarchats of Antioch, which has been considered as schismatic since the demise of Mgr. Meletias. A meeting of the three Patriarchs will be held for this purpose. The present Patriarch of Antioch, who was recently elected, suggests that the Metropolitans who were dismissed from the Electoral Synod at the time of the election of Mgr. Meltius be given a monthly pension of 1,000 piastres.
New Quarantine Regulations.

The Superior Council of Health at Constantinople has at last decided that the voluntary quarantine passed in Greece by arrivals from Alexandria will be recognised in the Ottoman ports upon the following conditions: these boats will go direct to the St. George lazaret, where the passengers and cargo for Greece will be disembarked, while those for Turkey and the crew will go through at this lazaret all the quarantine measures ordered in Ottoman ports.
Wrecked Steamer Sold.

Consequent upon poarparlers between the representatives of the Hadji Daoud Steam Navigation Company and the firm of Zarifi, of Constantinople, the vessel Constantinos which was wrecked some months ago on the Zegean coast, has been sold to the latter firm for 60,000 francs. This sum will suffice to pay off the sequestration on the Alexandria, which is detained at Suez.
The Mecca Pilgrimage.

Au Impatling matchas been issued designated spectacle of two over-developed Malsousse, struggling on the floor for half-an-hour at the time, hugging one another like bears and puffing like grampuses, are recommended to lose no chance of seeing the bouts. The Sunday morning's wrestling was slow. In the evening a dusky combatant called Mohamed threw the Austrian Sandorff and won in 11 minutes. Cylis (England) beat Clement (Belgium) after a close tussle. The umpire's decision was not unanimously applauded. Limousin and Shackmann grappled for an hour without any obvious result except mutual fatigue. The former was as slippery as an eel; the latter-who was the type of what the British schoolboy calls "a beefer"-showed immense vigour and in a Berserher outhurst tumbled with his opponent into the scenery, with the results that attended the bull's visit to the china shop

div.head: Alexandria Municipality.
div.p: The Charitable Grants Committee of the Alexandria Municipality has decided, in order not to stop the progress of the municipal budget, to demand that a lump sum should be inscribed in the budget so that the question of what grants should be made to charities should be discussed in detail in order that a well-considered and detailed report may be ultimately submitted to the Municipal Commission.
The following questions have been added to the order of the day of the meeting of the Municipal Commission to be held at 9 p.m. tomorrow:
1. Proposition de Mr. Kamel Bey Teymour, tendant a ajourner les ventes des parcelles des terrains des quais, fixees pour le mois de novembre 1906.
2. Proposition tendant a la nomination provisoire d'un ingenieur pour le travail preparatoire du transfert des echeches, demande parle Ministere.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: During the week ending on Sunday, 10 cases of plague were reported for the whole of Egypt, viz, three at Alexandria, on at Suez, and six near Samallout. The six cases discovered at Barhallant, near Samalout, have been investigated, but thus far it has proved impossible to discover how they arose. Meantime every possible precaution has been taken to prevent any further extension of the epidemie.
Between January 1 and November 4, 518 cases of plague were reported against 264 and 816 in the corresponding periods of 1905 and 1904.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Moberley Bey has been appointed to succeed the late Mr. Rone Carton de Wiart as governor of Tourah prison.
Dr. Graham Bey is expected back in Cairo from Europe to-morrow.
Count Gabriel de Zogheb has returned to Cairo from Europe.
We are requested to contradict the rumour that Mr. Reginald Silley, barrieter at law, of Alexandria, has been elevated to the Native Bench.
Mr. M., A. Caloyanni, barrister-at-law, has been appointed judge in the Cairo Native Court, in place of Judge Amos.

The Rev. Dr. Sheehan, DD., Ph. D., M.A., of Maynooth, Ireland, has been appointed a Commissioner of the Intermediate Board of Education, in place of the late Monsignor Molloy, of Dublin, who died suddenly at Aberdeen while attending the University Quarter Centenary celebrations there. Dr. Sheehan, who is a native of Waterford, is a brother of Kaimakam Sheehau Bey, of the Coast Guard Administration, and is one of the foremost of living classical scholars, having had a distinguished course in the German Universities before his ordination as a priest. He is also recognised as one of the best authorities on the living Irish speech and one of the best and idiomatic writers of the language.

The list of passengers by the Hohenzollern, which arrived from Marseilles yesterday includes:-Adly Yeghen Pasha, Capt. C.C. Barnes, Mme Choremi, Mme Constantin Choremi, Ahmed Fouad Pacha junior, Marquis de Freije, M. Kher, Mrs. Gottlieb, Mr. and Mrs. J. Karam, Mme. E. Karam, Dr. James F. Love, Mr. and Mrs. J. Marshall, Mr. and Mme Paravicini, Mr. and Mrs. F. Rowlatt, Mrs. F. A. Satow, Miss Dorothy Satow, Miss Joyce Satow, Baron H. von Stumm, Mrs. P.W. Stoat, Mme. Cl. Suares, Mlle. Suares, Mme. Despina Sinadino, Mme. Sadick Bey, Mme. Steinchneider, Mr. and Mme. von Tschudi, Mme and Mlle Tamvaco, Mr. and Mme Tivoli, Mr. Usherwood Robinson, Mr. and Mrs. K.E. Verschoyle, Mme Wunderlich (wife of the German Consul at Alexandria), Mrs. Wallich, Mr. E.H. Wallich, Mr. E. Zunaniri, Mr. and Mme Ziegler.

Miss Corlass looked very charming and danced delightfully: her rendering of the "Jewel of Asia" was perhaps a little wanting; it gave the impression of being too abrupt and dry. Miss O'Connor was very good: her improptu 'scrap' with fans against Miss Merra caused great amusement. Mr. Lester was also excellent, and showed a most consistent world weary spirit of resignation. Mr. Cole was in great form: desperate attempts were made to procure double encores to "Chin Chin Chinnman:" his stentorian admonition to the house to "be silent" was an encore in itself. The rest of the company have little enough to do, but they did it quite well, and the orchestra had quite recovered from their fit of tunelness of Saturday. Altogether it was a most spirited preformance, and left us an excellent memory of the company. We wish them luck, and shall always be glad to see them again in Cairo.

div.head: Cairo Opera Season.
div.p: The opera season at the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo, begins on the 26th inst. with "William Tell," and we are promised a good company and an excellent repertoire. M. LE's calais, of the Paris Opera (an excellent "tenore robustro"), M. Lorec, of the Bordeaux Opera (baritone), M. Durand, of the Opera Comique, among the basses, Mme Baron, of the Lyons Opera, (soprano) and Mme Chaix-Bonheur (contralto) come with excellent reputations.

Among the operas, of old favourites we are to have "William Tell," Haleiz's "La Juive," "The Huguenots," "Sigurd," "Samson and Delilah," "Faust," "Carmen" "Trovatore," "Romeo and Juliet," "Mireille," "Manon," "Werther," "Mignon," "Rigoletto," "The Daughter of the Regiment," and "Herodias." The novelties are Isidore de Lara's "Messlins," Massenet's "Cendrillon" (Cinderella) and his famous "Jongleur de notre Dame," Charpentier's "Louize," and opera which has been very highly praised, and Xaires Leroux's "Queen Fiammetta."

Subscriptions for the season, notice of which must be given by the 18th inst, include 60 performances, which will be given on Mondays, Tuesday, Thursdays, and Saturdays. The rates of subscription are as follows:- Baignoires and first boxes, L.E. 125; second boxes, L.E. 45; fautenils L.E. 12 ½ (half subscription L.E. 7); stalls L.E. 6 (half subscription L.E. 3 ½)

div.head: Bulletin De La Bourse
div.p: Auiourd'hui a midi et demie

Le marche a ouvert ce matin en pleine depression, pour se ressaisir un pen plus tard et cloturer relativement soutenu. Nombre de valeurs sont, cependant en baisse plus ou moins sensible. Cette reaction provient de la liquidation de fin de mois et de l'impression defavorable produite par la baisse du coton americain

La National Bank recale de 27 7/8 a 27 1/4, l'Alexandria Water de 13 7/8 a 13 3,4 la Daira de 17 5/16 a 17 1/4, la Cassa di Sconto de 243 1/4 a 242 l'ancienne et de 238 1/2 a 237 1/2 la nouvelle, lee Nungovich Hotels de 18 5/16 a 18 3/16, la Nile Land de 17 7/16 a 17 3/8, la Land Bank de 9 a 8 15/16, l'Urbaine de 6 11/16 a 6 19/32, le Credit Franco-Egyptien de 5 9/16 a 5 17/ 38 et la Banque d'Orient de 134 a 133.

Quant au Comptoir, tandis que l'action flechit de 7 1/8 et 6 7/8 a 7 1/16 et 6 13/16, la part de fondateur remonte de 52 1/2 a 53.

Les Estates sont tres fermes a 2 1/4 et ont donne lieu a heaucoup d'affaires, ainsi que le Comptoir et la Delta Land; cette derniere est un peu plus faible a 4 3/32 vendenrs. Sur le reste de la cote, le mouvement a e e presque nul.

Toutes les antres valenrs restent sans changement excepte l'union Fonciere qui perd encoure 1/16 a 6 7/16. Nous n'avona pas besoin de dire que ce prix estres avantageux, car l'Union Fonciere sera certainement dan quel ques jours l'une des devises les plus rechereheas de la cote. En effet, c'est a la fin de 1906 que la societe doit proclamer son premier bilan qui fera ressortir es situation exceptionuellement florisrante. Nous donnerons prochainement des reneseignements detailles a ce sujet

div.head:
Mutiny At Portsmouth
Naval Canteen Smashed Up.

div.p: A serious outbreak ocurred in the naval barracks at Portsmouth yesterday. 300 men on parade bolted indoors without orders during a rain equally. They were afterwards paraded in the Gymnasium, when the senior officer ordered the front rank, mostly composed of stokers, to kneel in order that he might better see and address them. So me of them hesitated one returned and was handed over to the naval police. His comrades, being relentful, afterwards smashed up the canteen and resolved to wreck the quarters of the officer. but the alarm being given, the whole force in the barracks was mobilised by bugle call and the rioters confronted with fixed bayonets. They eventually retired. After Commodore Stopford had listened to their grievances he ordered the release of the prisoner. (Reuter)

div.head:
France And Disarmament
M. Clemenceau's Policy.

div.p: The Chamber of Deputies approved by 395 votes to 96 M. Clemenceau's declaration, which stated that while the peace of the world depends on force of arms France cannot disarm, and that he will be careful to maintain and develop an alliance contracted in the interests of peace as well as tried frienships (Reuter)

Chamber of Deputies-The Ministerial declaration adds that the Cabinet will introduce a Bill for the suppression of courts marital, conciliating the rights of man with the necessities of national defence. It will accomplish the secularisation of the schools, will abrogate the Falloux law, will establish the liberty of the cults, and will realise workmen's pensions and the income tax
The Chamber passed a vote of confidence by 395 votes against 96. (Havas)
The government having refused to compensate the Greeks for the losses sustained in the recent anti-Greek riots, the Greek representative will go on leave, and will probably not return. (Reuter)

div.head:
The Search For The Pole
Peary To Make Second Attempt

div.p: Commander Peary is returning for repairs and additional supplies and will again make an attempt to reach the Pole. The recent dash was frustrated by a mild season; but despite the delays, owing to much borken ice and open water, he got within 203 miles of the Pole. (R.)

Mr. Keir Hardie, speaking at Edinburgh denied that Socialism or the Labour party bad received a set back from the result of the monicipal elections. The defeat of the Progressives in London meant the triumph of great electric and other trusts, which had spent 52000 fighting the elections. (Reuter)
The Naval Department contemplates bulding a more powerful ship than the Dreadnought. She is to have a displacement of 20,500 tons (Reuter)

div.head: The Indian Review.
div.p: The October number of the "Indian Review" contains an interesting article from an Indian publicist, "India's Imports". He arrives at the conclusion the people import goods of the value of RS 338 and silver of the value of 2 3/4 annas per head per annum, and this single fact, the writer avers, "is eveidence enough of the extremely poor economic condition of the people." Pandit Jwala Dott Joshi writing about 'The Impersonality of the British Indian Empire," suggests the desirability of a member of the Royal family of England governing India instead of a Viceroy as at repent.

div.head: Education In Egypt
div.p: Native Press Opinion
(From 'Al Moayad.")
"No advance can be made in the educational state of a nation unless the system of training in that nation answers all her needs". (Report of Lord Cromer, 1903)

The policy followed by the Ministry of Education in the system of training is that the primary schools should be the means of making those who attend them able as much as possible to read and write; and that the Ministry should endeavour to display to the Government its great attention and concern to advance arts. But the truth is that the ministry is absolutely indifferent on that point. The only object of the secondary and higher training is to prepare Government employes. Official training meets only some of the nation's wants and spreads among a fraction of the people. How many times has the Legislative Council raised its voice, asking that all regulations relating to educational training should be submitted to it? But the answer of the Government was always that the Legislative Council has nothing to do with regulations relating to educational training. Assuming that the rules of the Legislative Council do not allow its interference with such regulations, which is certainly untrue, are not the pupils that attend Government schools some of the members of that Council, or the sons of their kinsmen, or of those who chose them as representatives to examine the laws by which the nation is governed? Can such people have no right to examine the laws enacted for the training of their sons?

There are no schools in the country, except the Government schools, such as can give those who attend them the official certificates by which youths can be appointed to Government posts or can enter the higher schools. Otherwise we should say to the upper classes of the nation: "Why, then, you are free to send or not to send your sons to the Government schools as long as the Government does not wish to harmonise the system of training in accord with your own desires."

This is certainly an unreasonably arrogant policy of the Government, since the money spent on education from the Treasury is the money of the people, the money paid by parents as school fees for their sons is also the money of the people, and those who take charge of their education receive their salaries from the money of the people.

And yet the education budget is only decided upon after an accord with the Legislative Council. Not withstanding, if the members of the Legislative Council were to knock at the door of the Ministry of Education, and ask how their boys are being educated, the Ministry would tell them, through Mr. Dunlop, a person who expects to be worshipped his subordinates, that they are absolutely or other, such as the a system of education of the years of the really ignorant.

at one time changing them to that the Govern five and then altering them to four. The Government decides that the primary certificate should alone be sufficient to get a pupil employment and at another time they invent a new certificate a little higher than the primary, sometimes they occupy themselves with altering the degrees of the certificate so as to accord with the salaries and at other times they busy themselves with the reverse.

In this way education in Egypt has only one policy which is to prepare Government officials and, by getting the pupils to have no other wish or hope than becoming a Government official to destroy the free will of the native. As to that kind of education which is calculated to secure the cultivation of mental and ethical faculties it certainly cannot be found in the Government schools.

div.head: Mills For Egyptian Cotton.
div.p: The Lancashire spinners' prosperity is increasing the number of their rivals. No fewer than sixteen mills using Egyptian cotton, with close on one and a half million spindles, and fourteen spinning American cotton, with 1,215 million spindles, have recently been got to work. Eleven mills spinning Egyptian or American, with over 900,000 spindles, were partially at work, and no fewer than thirty-seven new mills, which would have over three million spindles, were in course of erection, making a total of nearly six and a half million new spindles, as compared with about twelve months ago.

div.head: Egypt's Demand For Gold.
div.p: City Opinion.

The "Statist," of the 27th ulto., considers that the advance in the Bank rate has so far failed to attain its object. It has not diverted the demand for gold for Egypt from London, and it has not yet enabled the Bank to secure any gold balance from abroad. Last week we stated that nearly a million of gold would be withdrawn from the Bank of England for Egypt last Saturday; the actual amount shipped was 990,000. Since then another sum of 100,000 in gold has been sent to Egypt, as well as 300,000 to Constantinople. Now we learn that another shipment of 300,000 of gold to Egypt is to be made by the Bank of England tomorrow, and there are rumours that the total amount to be sent may be even larger. How much more gold will be sent to Egypt no one knows. Telegrams have been received from Egypt affirming that additional shipments are necessary, while other reports are to the effect that gold is no longer moving out to the Egyptian interior to pay for the crops, but that gold has already begun to return to the banks. The amount of gold that has so far been sent to Egypt is over 5,000,000 against a normal 3,000,000 to 4,000,000. In view of the price of cotton, it is calculated that the total amount of gold needed to pay for the crop is about 3,000,000 more than last year.

Should the demand for gold for Egypt be larger than is now estimated, it may become necessary for the Bank to take further action; but, so far as can now be seen, no fresh advance in the rate will be necessary. A slight reaction in the American exchange today has to be recorded, but it is most improbable that the authorities in the United States will permit the exchange to fall low enough to enable gold to be purchased in the London open market. Early next week over a million of gold will be in the market from South Africa, and there is not much doubt that the Bank will succeed in securing pratically the whole of this sum. On the other hand, the usual movement of gold to Scotland and to Ireland at the end of October has already commenced. Taking into account that 250,000 of gold previously "earmarked" for account of an Egyptian bank has today been "unearmarked," and, placing this against the probable shipments of gold tomorrow, the prospects are in favour of no appreciable reduction in the Bank's reserve in the week ending Wednesday next.

The heavy withdrawal of gold for Egypt in the past week was partly neutralised by the return of cash crom the country; and the net loss of cash for the week ended Wednesday last was 674,000, the Bank's reserve being reduced to 18,188,000. Although it is impossible to speak with certainty, in view of our inability to measure the extent of the Egyptian demand, the indications are favourable to the view we expressed last week that the Bank of England will succeed in securing a large amount of gold from abroad during November; that these gold arrivals will increase the reserve sufficiently to provide for the usual large outflow or cash to the provinces during December; and that the Bank's reserve in December will not

div.head: Army and Navy.
div.p: London, October 27.
Recruiting is being pushed for the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, and Royal Dublin Fusiliers, both of which require a good many men to fill gaps in the home battalions.
It is expected that the Dreadnought will be ready for sea in about three months' time. As already intimated, her maiden commission will be as flagship of the Channel Fleet.

The command of the 2nd Battalion Dorsetshire Regiment, which recently went from England to Wellington, Madras, has been given to Major WJ Bonus, D.S.O., the second in command (who brought it out) in su cession to Colonel H.E. Lynch, who has retired on completion of the regulation period. Lieutenant Colonel Bonus served in the Dorsets when they were stationed in Egypt some years ago.

As the recent reduction of the establishment of depots, Royal Garrison Artillery, and further reductions which will shortly be carried out in service units, will cause a large number of supernumerary non-commissioned officers to be created, it has been decided by the Army Council that the following procedure in the Royal Garrison Artillery is to be adopted with a view to removing the block in promotion:- Continuance in the service beyond 21 years of non-comissioned officers (including Permanent Staff of Militia and Volunteers) on the home establishment is to cease for the present. In the case of those who eplisted as boys, the completion of 21 years' service will reckon from the date of attaining 18 years of age. In the case of those non commissioned officers on the home establishment who have already completed 21 years man's service, four months notice is to be given them, from 1st November 1906, on the termination of each period they are to be discharged on reduction of establishment. Staff sergeants under 40 years of age eligible for promotion to warrant rank may, however, be permitted to serve until they reach that age. This order will not affect non-commissioned officers belonding to the bands. Threning 9 3s thus caused will not be filled by png's Birthday. Offical preference to the War Officat the British Consulate.
